data.title: Money Laundering
data.meta_description: EU PEP-List - EU-List of prominent public functions - Prominent public functions at national level, at the level of International Organisations and at the level of the European Union Institutions and Bodies
data.text:
EU PEP-List – EU-List of prominent public functions – Prominent public functions at national level, at the level of International Organisations and at the level of the European Union Institutions and Bodies

Austria (AT)

List of prominent public functions

Politically exposed person: a natural person exercising or having exercised prominent public functions. This includes in particular:

No public function referred to above is to be understood as covering middle-ranking or more junior officials.

List of prominent public functions of international organisations accredited on the territory of Austria according to Art. 3 para. 10 FM-AML Act

Belgium (BE)

List of the precise functions whose performers are to be regarded as politically exposed persons

Pursuant to the requirement laid down in Article 20a(1) of Directive (EU) 2015/849 of the Europeen Parliament and of the Council (1), what follows is a list of the precise functions whose performers are to be regarded as politically exposed persons. This list is set out in Article N4 of the law of 18 September 2017 (2):

List of public functions within the international organisations represented in Belgium

Cyprus (CY)

Cyprus – Notification of the authorities, pursuant to Article 20a of Directive (EU) 2015/849

In accordance with the definition laid down in Article 2 of the Laws of 2007-2021 on Preventing and Combating Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing, please find below the ‘prominent public functions’ in Cyprus through the definition of ‘politically exposed persons’ in that Law.

Czech Republic (CZ)

National list of PEP functions:

President of the Republic + head of the Office of the President of the Republic

Prime Minister

Head of a central government body and their stand-in (deputy, state secretary):

Member of the Czech Parliament

Member of the governing body of a political party and of a political movement – chair, vice-chairs;

Head of local government

Members of supreme courts, of constitutional courts or of other high-level judicial bodies, the decisions of which are not subject to further appeal except in exceptional circumstances

Member of the board of the central bank

Senior officer in the armed or other uniformed forces

Member or representative of a member, if the member is a legal entity, of the statutory body of a public corporation

Ambassador or Head of Diplomatic Mission, or natural person who holds or has held a similar function in another State, in an institution of the European Union (3) or in an international organisation

Representation of international organisations accredited to the Czech Republic

Supreme Audit Office (Nejvyšší kontrolní úřad)

List of Estonian positions whose holders are deemed to be politically exposed persons

This Regulation is enacted on the basis of Section 91(5) of the Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Prevention Act [rahapesu ja terrorismi rahastamise tõkestamise seadus].

Politically exposed persons

Finland (FI)

Government Decree on the prominent public functions referred to in the Act on preventing money laundering and terrorist financing 9 May 2019/610

The legislation has been monitored up to Statutes of Finland No 675/2020.

By Government decision, the following is enacted pursuant to Chapter 1, Section 4(2) of the Act on preventing money laundering and terrorist financing (444/2017), as worded in Act 573/2019:

Section 1 – Scope of application

This Decree lays down the prominent public functions referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11) of Act 444/2017 on preventing money laundering and terrorist financing (hereinafter ‘the Money Laundering Act’), whereby persons entrusted or having been entrusted with such functions should be considered politically exposed persons.

Section 2 – Head of state, head of government, minister, deputy or assistant minister

The functions of a head of state, head of government, minister, or deputy or assistant minister as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(a) of the Money Laundering Act consist of:

Section 3 – Member of Parliament [parlamentti]

The functions of members of Parliament [parlamentti] as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(b) of the Money Laundering Act consist of:

Section 4 – Member of the governing body [johtoelin] of a political party [poliittinen puolue]

A political party [poliittinen puolue] within the meaning of Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(c) of the Money Laundering Act refers to a party [puolue] entered in the register of parties [puoluerekisteri] on the basis of Section 2 of Act 10/1969 on Political Parties.

The functions of members of the governing body [johtoelin] of a political party [poliittinen puolue] consist of the functions of the chairperson and members of the party committee [puolueen hallitus].

The functions of members of the governing body [johtoelin] of a political party [poliittinen puolue] also consist of the functions of the deputy of a person referred to in Subsection 2.

Section 5 – Member of the supreme court [ylin tuomioistuin], constitutional court [perustuslakituomioistuin] or other corresponding judicial body [oikeuselin]

The functions as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(d) of the Money Laundering Act of members of the supreme court [ylin tuomioistuin], constitutional court [perustuslakituomioistuin] or other corresponding judicial body [oikeuselin] whose decisions are not subject to appeal, except in exceptional cases consist of:

The functions of members of the supreme court [ylin tuomioistuin], constitutional court [perustuslakituomioistuin] or other corresponding judicial body [oikeuselin] also include the functions of the deputy of a person referred to in Subsection 1.

Section 6 – Member of a court of auditors [tilintarkastustuomioistuin] or of the highest decision-making bodies [ylin päättävä elin] which audit the financial management of the State [valtio] and are equivalent to the National Audit Office of Finland [Valtiontalouden tarkastusvirasto]

The functions as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(e) of the Money Laundering Act of members of a court of auditors [tilintarkastustuomioistuin] or of the highest decision-making bodies [ylin päättävä elin] which audit the financial management of the State and are equivalent to the National Audit office [Valtiontalouden tarkastusvirasto] consist of the functions of the auditor-general of the National Audit Office of Finland [Valtiontalouden tarkastusvirasto].

Section 7 – Member of the board of directors [johtokunta] of the central bank [keskuspankki]

The functions of members of the board of directors [johtokunta] of the central bank [keskuspankki] as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(f) of the Money Laundering Act consist of the functions of members of the board of directors [johtokunta] of the Bank of Finland [Suomen Pankki].

Section 8 – Ambassador or chargé d’affaires

The functions of ambassadors as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(g) of the Money Laundering Act consist of the functions of the head of mission [edustusto] governing an embassy [suurlähetystö], permanent representation [pysyvä edustusto], special mission [erityisedustusto] or consulate-general [pääkonsulaatti].

The functions of chargés d’affaires as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(g) of the Money Laundering Act consist of the functions of the chargé d’affaires ad interim acting as deputy ambassador as referred to in Article 19(1) of the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations.

Section 9 – Officer in the armed forces [puolustusvoimat] holding the rank of general or higher

The functions of officers in the armed forces [puolustusvoimat] holding the rank of general or higher as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(h) of the Money Laundering Act consist of the functions of the chief of defence, chief of the military headquarters [Pääesikunta], generals and admirals.

Section 10 – Member of the administrative [hallintoelin], management [johtoelin] or supervisory bodies [valvontaelin] of wholly state-owned enterprises [valtion kokonaan omistama yritys]

Wholly state-owned enterprises [valtion kokonaan omistama yritys] as referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(i) of the Money Laundering Act consist of enterprises [yhtiö] wholly owned by the State [valtio] either directly or indirectly.

The functions of members of the administrative [hallintoelin], management [johtoelin] or supervisory bodies [valvontaelin] of wholly state-owned enterprises [valtion kokonaan omistama yritys] as referred to in Subsection 1 above consist of the functions of the chairperson and members of the board of directors [hallitus], the managing director and the chairperson and members of the administrative board [hallintoneuvosto] of the enterprise [yhtiö].

The functions of members of the administrative [hallintoelin], management [johtoelin] or supervisory bodies [valvontaelin] of wholly state-owned enterprises [valtion kokonaan omistama yritys] also comprise the functions of the deputy of a person referred to in Subsection 2 and of the deputy managing director.

Section 11 – Director, deputy director or member of the board [hallitus] of an international organisation [kansainvälinen yhteisö]

The international organisations [kansainvälinen yhteisö] referred to in Chapter 1, Section 4(11)(j) of the Money Laundering Act are organisations [organisaatio]:

The international organisations [kansainvälinen yhteisö] referred to in Subsection 1 above consist of:

The functions of a director, deputy director or member of the board [hallitus] of an international organisation [kansainvälinen yhteisö] referred to above in this section consist of the functions of the secretary-general, secretary (general), chairperson, and chairperson and members of the board of directors [hallitus] of the international organisation [kansainvälinen yhteisö].

The functions of a director, deputy director or member of the board [hallitus] of an international organisation [kansainvälinen yhteisö] also consist of the functions of the deputy of a person referred to in subsection 3.

Section 12 – Entry into force

This Decree shall enter into force on 15 May 2019.

Directive (EU) 2018/843 of the European Parliament and of the Council (32018L0843) (OJ L 156, 19.6.2018, p. 43).

Ireland (IE)

Information provided by Ireland in respect of Article 20a of Directive (EU) 2015/849

General definition of ‘prominent public function’

A ‘prominent public function,’ where not elsewhere defined, shall be any person holding an office or other position in a public body in respect of which the remuneration is not less than the lowest remuneration in relation to the position of Deputy Secretary-General in the Civil Service (7).

Application of provisions to roles in the State

Malta (MT)

List of Politically Exposed Persons

Heads of State, Heads of Government, Ministers, Deputy or Assistant Ministers, Parliamentary Secretaries, and Head of Secretariat:

Members of the governing bodies of political parties (limited to political parties represented in the House of Representatives):

Members of Superior, Supreme, and Constitutional Courts or of other high-level judicial bodies:

Members of Courts of Auditors, or of the board of the Central Banks:

Ambassadors, Chargé d’Affaires and High-Ranking Officials in the Armed Forces or International Organisations accredited in Malta:

Other Senior State and Government Officials:

The following were chosen under State-Owned Enterprises:

Members of the administrative, Management or Supervisory boards including Chairpersons, Chief Executive Officers and Board of Directors of State-Owned Enterprises (state-owned enterprises are here to be construed as those profit enterprises where that state has ownership of more than 50 %, or where information reasonable available points to the state having other control through other means, such as having a preferential/golden share:

The following were chosen under this Category:

Top Officials of State and Public Agencies, Authorities, Entities, Constitutional Bodies and Government Departments which carry out any of the hereunder activities or function or have the hereunder responsibilities:

Issuance of certain licences, authorisations or permits which authorise the carrying out of certain operations/activities, that could potentially generate considerable turnover:

Imposition of administrative fines of substantial value or administrative measures that have a significant financial effect (this would include, suspension and withdrawal of Licenses or restriction of business):

Approval or awarding of high value contracts or tenders (of a value in excess of EUR 250K):

Granting of citizenship or residency in exchange of capital transfers, purchase of property or government bonds, or investment in corporate entities:

Schemes

As regards International Organisations, Malta confirms there are no International Organisations that fall within the term ‘international organisations accredited on the territory’, whereby it would be deemed necessary to apply enhanced due diligence rules to holders in office, in line with guidelines provided by the Commission.

Netherlands (NL)

List of prominent public functions in the Netherlands

a. Heads of state, heads of government, ministers and deputy or assistant ministers

b. Members of parliament or of a similar legislative body

c. Members of the governing body of a political party

d. Members of a supreme court, constitutional court or other high-level judicial body, the decisions of which are not subject to further appeal, except in exceptional circumstances

e. Members of a court of auditors or the board of a central bank

f. Ambassadors, chargés d’affaires and high-ranking officers in the armed forces

g. Members of the administrative, management or supervisory body of a state-owned enterprise

There are no companies in the Netherlands that meet the definition of a state enterprise.

h. Directors, deputy directors and members of the board or equivalent function of an international organisation

Portugal (PT)

List of high-level prominent public functions

The present list is drawn up according to the sequence laid down in Article 2(1)(cc) of Law No 83/2017 of 18 August 2017, as amended by Law No 58/2020 of 31 August 2020. Furthermore, account is taken of the list of precedents contained in Law No 40/2006 of 25 August 2006 (Law on Precedents of the Portuguese State Protocol), the organisational structure of the 22nd Constitutional Government, the Statute of Holders of Political Posts and High-Ranking Public Posts, the Political and Administrative Statutes of the Autonomous Region of the Azores and the Political and Administrative Statutes of the Autonomous Region of Madeira, and the Rules on the organisation and functioning of bodies of direct and indirect State administration and of regional and local administration, including the public business sector.

List of high-level prominent public functions:

EUROPEAN UNION INSTITUTIONS AND BODIES

List of functions at the level of the European Union institutions and bodies as set out in Decision C(2022) 3105

According to Commission Decision C(2022) 3105 of 20 May 2022 (9) the following functions qualify as prominent public functions in the Union institutions and bodies:

(1) Directive (EU) 2015/849 of the Europeen Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2015 on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Commission Directive 2006/70/EC (OJ L 141, 5.6.2015, p. 73).

(2) Law of 18 September 2017 on the prevention of money-laundering and the financing of terrorism, and on restricting the use of cash.

(3) Pursuant to Article 20a of Directive (EU) 2015/849 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2015 on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Commission Directive 2006/70/EC, as amended by Directive (EU) 2018/843 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 May 2018, the European Commission is to compile and keep up to date the list of the exact functions which qualify as prominent public functions at the level of Union institutions and bodies. That list must also include any function which may be entrusted to representatives of third countries and of international bodies accredited at European Union level.

(4) The list shows the functions of office holders in accordance with amending directive (EU) 2018/843 within the meaning of Section 1(12) of the Money Laundering Act (revised version) in Germany. Corresponding office holders from other Member States and third countries are also politically exposed persons within the meaning of amending directive (EU) 2018/843 and the Money Laundering Act (revised version).

(5) See recital 3 of Directive (EC) 2006/70.

(6) https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/internationale-organisationen/uno/03-uno-in-deutschland/-/257900.

(7) The pay scale for a Deputy Secretary is issued by the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform and is subject to change. The most up-to-date pay scale should be used for the purposes of identifying a person entrusted with a prominent public function. The current pay scale for a Deputy Secretary is set out in Circular 12/2020 ‘Application of 1 October 2020 pay adjustments’. Available at: https://www.gov.ie/en/circular/39b2c-circular-12-2020-application-of-1st-of-october-2020-pay-adjustments/.

(8) ‘State-owned enterprise’ means any undertaking over which the public authorities may exercise directly or indirectly a dominant influence within the meaning of Article 2(b) of Commission Directive 2006/111/EC of 16 November 2006.

(9) Commission Decision C(2022) 3105 of 20 May 2022 on the exact functions that qualify as prominent public functions in the European Union institutions and bodies (OJ C, C/2023/611, 31.10.2023, ELI: http://data.europa.eu/eli/C/2023/611/oj).
